Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing Climate Models by Feedback Analysis Using Atmospheric Infrared Sounder (AIRS) and Global Positioning System (GPS) Radio Occultation Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Outgoing longwave spectra obtained by the Atmospheric Infrared Sounder (AIRS) and GPS radio occultation data obtained by the CHAMP (Challenging Mini-satellite Payload) and COSMIC (Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere and Climate) missions will be analyzed to provide observational constraints on longwave feedbacks and radiative forcing in the climate system. The high-spectral-resolution radiance measurements of AIRS contain the fingerprints of radiative forcing by a variety of atmospheric thermodynamic variables and constituent concentrations, and these fingerprints lead directly to longwave greenhouse forcing and atmospheric feedbacks. Because clouds and surface temperature contribute similar spectral signatures, radio occultation will provide the information to distinguish between the two.

The investigators found, under their previous NSF support, that radio occultation trends constrain the surface air temperature response of climate models while infrared spectral radiance trends unambiguously constrain radiative forcing of the climate and the longwave feedbacks in climate models. Now they will apply these findings to the aforementioned satellite data to obtain estimates of radiative forcing by well-mixed greenhouse gases globally to at least 10% uncertainty, to estimate tropical water vapor and cloud longwave feedbacks to ~7% uncertainty by anomaly analysis, and to begin the estimation of global longwave feedbacks by trend analysis, albeit with large uncertainties due to natural variability.

Broader impacts of this work lie in its use of optimal fingerprinting using multiple data types to test climate models against satellite data, and in the field of climate prediction. Highly accurate and reliable data will be used to provide strong observational constraints on climate models. The ultimate goal of this research program is to improve our skill at decadal scale climate projection. In addition, graduated students from the joint Harvard and University of Michigan efforts will be supported.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project undertaken was a collaboration between the University of Michigan and Harvard University. The outcomes described herein are those produced at Harvard University, PI Dr. Stephen Leroy. The overall goal of the proposed research was to test climate models according to the trends they predict in data types that are rich in information content and of sufficient accuracy. The data was outgoing longwave spectra obtained by the Atmospheric Infrared Sounder (AIRS) and radio occultation data obtained by the Challenging Mini-satellite Payload (CHAMP) and the Constellation Observing System for Meteorology, Ionosphere, and Climate (COSMIC). In the course of this effort we developed and documented retrieval system for radio occultation suitable for climate purposes and we completed the theoretical underpinnings for inferring climate feedbacks from longwave spectral data.

For GPS radio occultation, we tuned the radio occultation processing system originally constructed by Dr. Michael Gorbunov, a visiting scientist on this project, so that it is suited to processing COSMIC data. We fully documented the system and published it in the peer-reviewed literature. The funded collaboration with Dr. Gorbunov also produced a theoretical work on the utility of Wigner distribution functions for interpreting atmospheric inhomogeneity and multi-path in radio occultation data. More so than other retrieval techniques, it clarifies the presence of multi-path and spherical asymmetry in the atmosphere along the path of the occultation ray. In collaboration with Drs. Chi Ao and Olga Verkhoglyadova (JPL), we devised a binning scheme for radio occultation that extracts maximum spatial-temporal information from randomly distributed global data without introducing a bias. Radio occultation distributions contain weak singularities because of the geometry of the orbits of the GPS satellites. It is important to account for these singularities when forming a climatology of radio occultation data.

We extended information content studies to account for clouds in thermal infrared spectra. We found that in trends in cloudy infrared spectra, the feedbacks associated with upper air temperature, humidity, and cloud feedbacks become very difficult to distinguish. Nevertheless, the incorporation of radio occultation data into the framework makes it possible to resolve many of the ambiguities because the information in radio occultation is highly complementary to the information in thermal infrared spectra. In order to accomplish these investigations, we constructed an optimal detection framework that is useful for scientific inference and fully accounts for uncertainty in modeling signals of climate change. In the near future it should be possible to quantify the anthropogenic greenhouse forcing of climate using AIRS and IASI data, but only after optimal fingerprints that accounts for realistic uncertainties due to clouds can be constructed.

Incidental to the research was an investigation into a quantitative technique to evaluate different data types according to their ability to improve inter-decadal climate prediction. We found that space-based data types, especially hyperspectral thermal infrared data, are better at improving climate prediction than in situ data types. While the investigation was constrained by a very limited ensemble of climate models, it clearly points in the direction of a more comprehensive investigation using a perturbed physics ensemble.
